summary: Email chain between defense attorney Laura Menninger and Assistant U.S. Attorney regarding discovery issues in US v. Maxwell, focusing on the review of highly confidential images/videos, hard drives, and boots seized from Epstein's properties. The correspondence details logistical arrangements, disputes over the number of nude images, and technical problems with accessing discovery materials.

persons.name: Laura Menninger
persons.context: Partner at Haddon, Morgan & Foreman, P.C. representing Ghislaine Maxwell. She is corresponding with the prosecution about discovery issues, including reviewing highly confidential images, hard drives, and boots seized from Epstein's properties.

persons.name: Jeff Pagliuca
persons.context: Contractor for the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York, copied on emails regarding discovery conferral in US v. Maxwell.

persons.name: Bobbi Sternheim
persons.context: Attorney copied on emails regarding discovery issues in US v. Maxwell, appears to be involved in the legal proceedings.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in US v. Maxwell, referenced as the client of Laura Menninger. The emails discuss her right to review discovery materials and logistical issues with her accessing them at the MDC (Metropolitan Detention Center).

persons.name: Judge Nathan
persons.context: Presiding judge in US v. Maxwell, referenced in relation to an order (Dkt. No. 322) that is the subject of a meet and confer.

connections.description: Laura Menninger is the defense attorney representing Ghislaine Maxwell in the criminal case.
They are corresponding professionally regarding discovery logistics and issues in US v. Maxwell.
The discovery materials being discussed (images, hard drives, boots) were seized from Epstein's properties, linking Maxwell to the Epstein investigation.

events.title: Scheduled Trial Date for US v. Maxwell
events.description: The trial for United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell is scheduled to begin on November 29, 2021.

events.title: Proposed Review of Hard Drives and Boots
events.description: Defense attorney Laura Menninger proposes to review hard drives and boots seized as evidence at the FBI office in Colorado.

events.title: Scheduled Evidence Review in Denver
events.description: A review of evidence (hard drives and boots) is scheduled to take place at an FBI office in Denver, Colorado.

events.title: FBI Report on HC Images and Videos
events.description: An FBI report dated January 27, 2021, indicates approximately 33,747 highly confidential images and 895 videos were identified from a digital review of CART-processed evidence from Epstein's devices.

locations: Denver, Colorado (FBI office where evidence review is to take place)
New York, NY (Southern District of New York U.S. Attorney's Office and location of case file)
Epstein's New York residence (source of seized CDs)
Epstein's private island (referenced in context of a 3D scan)
keyFacts: The government possesses approximately 40,000 images extracted from CDs seized from Epstein's New York residence, with thousands designated as 'Highly Confidential' (HC).
A significant discrepancy exists between an initial verbal estimate of ~2,100 HC images from Epstein's devices and an FBI report citing ~33,747 HC images and 895 HC videos.
The defense is experiencing major technical difficulties reviewing discovery, including corrupt files, missing metadata, and unreadable photo formats, hindering trial preparation.
Evidence includes 'boots' recently taken into evidence, which the defense sought to examine in Colorado along with hard drives containing HC materials.
The protective order defines 'Highly Confidential' material broadly to include any nude, partially-nude, or sexualized depictions, not limited to child pornography.
